name: pss10_en
title: Perceived Stress Scale-10 (PSS-10)
description: The PSS-10 measures the degree to which individuals perceive their life situations as stressful over the past month. It focuses on the subjective appraisal of stress rather than the objective stressors themselves.
disclaimer: This questionnaire is for informational and self-monitoring purposes only and does not diagnose a stress disorder. Only a qualified mental health professional can provide a diagnosis.
source: Developed by Sheldon Cohen. Available at pss.stress.info

questions.title: In the last month, how often have you been bothered by the things that happened unexpectedly?
In the last month, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?
In the last month, how often have you felt nervous and 'stressed'?
In the last month, how often have you felt confident about your ability to handle your personal problems?
In the last month, how often have you felt that things were going your way?
In the last month, how often have you found that you could not cope with all the things you had to do?
In the last month, how often have you been able to control irritations in your life?
In the last month, how often have you felt that you were on top of things?
In the last month, how often have you been angered because of things that happened that were outside of your control?
In the last month, how often have you felt difficulties were piling up so high that you could not overcome them?

interpretation.label: Low perceived stress
interpretation.recommendation: Your responses suggest a low level of perceived stress. You appear to be managing daily stressors effectively.

interpretation.label: Moderate perceived stress
interpretation.recommendation: Your responses suggest a moderate level of perceived stress. Exploring stress management techniques or self-care strategies could be beneficial.

interpretation.label: High perceived stress
interpretation.recommendation: Your responses suggest a high level of perceived stress. It is recommended to explore stress reduction techniques and consider professional support if stress is significantly impacting your well-being.
